name: Undergraduate Research Assistant
company: Computational Ecology Lab at UC Santa Cruz
description: I contributed to research in efficient connectivity computation for bird species in Python/PyTorch and R. I worked on methods for processing large amounts of geospatial data efficiently and automated input layer generation for our connectivity computation algorithm, which currently runs over 1,000x faster than similar algorithms. Such an algorithm helps ecologists model the effects of habitat fragmentation on bird populations and understand how to best mitigate those effects through habitat restoration.

name: Lead Web Developer
company: Tech4Good Lab at UC Santa Cruz
description: Over several academic quarters, I led 50+ students in learning web development by collaboratively building web applications for research initiatives in social computing. This entailed guiding students through concepts such as HTML, SCSS, TypeScript, Angular, NgRx, RxJS, and Firebase, handling task delegation, providing detailed feedback in code reviews, and defining long-term development objectives of ongoing projects.

name: Software Engineering Intern
description: I participated in two internships at JPL, in which I worked with the Deep Space Network Emulator (DSNE) team to produce automation software for creating DSNE configuration files and DSNE test scripts. In doing so, I gained experience in working with large code systems written in Perl, Tcl, and C, as well as in web application development using HTML, CSS, Bootstrap, jQuery, and Python.

name: Google Summer of Code Mentor
company: UC Santa Cruz Open Source Program Office (UCSC OSPO)
description: I mentored two Google Summer of Code participants in building Causeway, a web application that teaches learners web development using a microrole-based hierarchy, and Compass Goals, an associated exemplar application used in Causeway. I performed regular check-ins with the participants every week to discuss the projects, which involved technologies such as Typescript, Angular, and Firebase, and reviewed 30+ pull requests addressing new features and bugs in detail.

name: Pintos Projects
description: I collaborated with a partner on Stanford's Pintos projects in C. These projects developed a thorough understanding of operating system concepts through the implementation of support for user programs, virtual memory, and file systems in an existing operating system. In the process, I also strengthened my skills in C programming and debugging.

name: Kakaw!
description: Over eight weeks, I worked in a team of six to produce Kakaw!, an application that facilitates learning and review via live quiz sessions. This application involved a tech stack of TypeScript, React, Tailwind CSS, Next.js, and Express.js; I primarily worked on building pages in the frontend and integrating them with the server backend. Our team practiced Agile methodologies throughout development, including regular standup meetings, sprint planning, and sprint reviews.
